none: Letter to Louis L. McInnis from James Garrison, April 30, 1885
Letter to Louis L. McInnis from James Garrison, April 30, 1885
Box 1 Louis L. McInnis Papers/Box 1 Folder 19 Louis L. McInnis Papers

body.value:
[Header]
CAPITOL HOTEL,
Jno. R. Mahone, Proprietor.

Marshall, Texas, April 30th 1885

Prof. L. L. McInnis,
College Station,
Texas,

Dear Sir:-

Be kind
enough to order a suit
for Cadet Garrison, and
I will pay for it.

Your friend truly,
[Signature]
Jas. E. Garrison

First, I'm setting the stage: I'm a professional transcriptionist, and my job is to accurately reproduce the text from this image. The rules are clear: top-to-bottom reading, preserving every detail (spelling, punctuation – even if it's odd), and using specific HTML tags where specified. No commentary, just the text. Underneath the signature, there is a line with two tick marks in the middle. Now for the nitty-gritty transcription. I know "CAPITOL HOTEL" is stylized, so I'll keep the capitalization, but treat it as plain text. The "Jno. R. Mahone, Proprietor." will get the `` treatment. When I get to the body, I'm going to take it line by line: "Be kind", "enough to order a suit", "for Cadet Garrison, and", "I will pay for it." I'll need to carefully examine the handwriting. The "k" in "kind" looks a bit like a "16", but based on context, it's definitely "kind". I will carefully note if parts of words or the full words appear merged; the goal is to make a faithful reproduction of the image. The closing and signature are fairly clear: "Your friend truly," and "Jas. E. Garrison". The "E" is a bit curly, but I'm reasonably confident it's an "E". I'll mark the signature with a label.
